columns.text: In this problem, we need to discuss whether the assumption that the working capital is recovered at the end of the project is valid or not.
The working capital refers to the difference between the company's assets and their liabilities. This measures how much money is available for the business.

The assumption that the working capital is recovered at the end of the project is an optimistic and therefore a valid assumption since we are assuming that at the end of the project, the worst case that we should end up with is breaking even.

However, there are instances wherein this assumption is not valid especially if the project sustained a lot of losses and incurred debt during the duration of the project. If we assume that the working capital is recovered in this scenario, then the project would go under.
In this task, we are asked to explain if it is reasonable to assume that a firm would recover all of the working capital invested in a project based on capital budgeting practices.

This assumption is most likely an overgeneralization. 

- First, all accounts payable should be compensated. 

- Second, existing funds' working capital component will be procured. Following all of that, several other accounts receivable would never be obtained, and some stockpiles may never be sold. 

- Third, those same liabilities are exacerbated because collection traded above cost (and therefore not supplanted at the final moment of the operating phase) increases working capital. 

These repercussions tend to cancel each other out.

textbook.authors: Bradford D. Jordan, Randolph W. Westerfield, Stephen A. Ross
textbook.title: Fundamentals of Corporate Finance
